• The Dodd-Frank Act amended the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit emergency lending programs for specific companies.
• Safe harbor provisions in bankruptcy allow certain financial and derivative contracts to be exempt from the automatic stay.
• The Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) gives FDIC the authority to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy.
• Efforts are being made to improve cross-border coordination for the resolution of failed large financial companies. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820.
* The General Allotment Act of 1887 divided Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members.
* The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the federal government's trust period.
* The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for managing trust funds, maintaining land records, and probating estates.
* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) has implemented trust fund management reforms.
* OST relies on contractors for trust reform activities, with significant funding allocated to contracts.
* Interior has provided retention allowances and performance awards to SES managers at OST, with oversight from the Executive Resources Board.
</summary>

<summary>
* The electricity industry consists of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* The smart grid vision aims to modernize the electricity grid for reliability, efficiency, and integration of renewable energy sources.
* The federal government and state governments oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale electricity sales and transmission.
* NERC is responsible for ensuring the reliability of the bulk power system through mandatory standards.
* Cyber threats to the electricity industry come from various sources and can have serious impacts on the grid.
* NIST and FERC have developed cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems to protect against cyber threats.
* The industry faces challenges in monitoring cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, and adopting comprehensive cybersecurity approaches.
* Metrics for evaluating cybersecurity effectiveness and information sharing are essential for protecting smart grid systems.
* FERC has taken steps to address cybersecurity challenges, including directing NERC to revise critical infrastructure protection standards.
* Continued attention is needed to mitigate the evolving cyber threats facing the electricity grid. 
</summary>

<summary> 
• The report discusses the decision-making process and coordination with relevant agencies for the extension of the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) by the Department of the Treasury. 
• The report also highlights the analytical framework and quantitative indicators used by Treasury to decide to extend TARP, focusing on factors such as housing market indicators, small business lending, and support to securitization markets. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Mission-critical skills gaps in federal workforce pose high risk to the nation
• Skills gaps impede government from serving public effectively
• Factors contributing to skills gaps include insufficient number of people and lack of appropriate skills
• Budget pressures, changing nature of work, and potential wave of retirements exacerbate skills gaps
• Over 34% of federal employees eligible to retire by 2020
• Challenges in classification system, recruiting, pay system, performance management, and employee engagement
• Federal workforce requires more advanced skills and degrees than private sector
• Need to balance size and composition of federal workforce to deliver high-quality services
• Challenges in updating federal compensation system to be more market-based and performance-oriented
• Recommendations include strengthening hiring efforts, modernizing classification system, addressing poor performance, and improving human resource capacity
</summary>

<summary>
• About 90% of the costs associated with GWOT fall into military personnel and operation and maintenance accounts.
• Estimating the cost of ongoing military operations is difficult due to changing operational requirements.
• DOD uses transfer authority to shift funds between appropriation accounts.
• In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, military services received supplemental appropriations for GWOT expenses.
• DOD increased annual appropriation requests by more than $10 billion per year to support GWOT.
• The military services lost visibility over funds provided through annual appropriations for GWOT.
• DOD did not explicitly take into account the additional funds provided through annual appropriations when addressing GWOT funding needs.
• The military services projected gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations for GWOT in fiscal year 2005.
• DOD and the military services planned to take actions to cover any gaps in GWOT funding, including transferring funds and reducing planned spending.
</summary>

<summary>
* USDA and FDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products, as well as other foods, respectively.
* Both agencies work to ensure food safety through a regulatory system of preventive controls, including the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system.
* FDA and USDA have taken actions to enhance food security in response to the potential for deliberate contamination of agriculture and food products.
* The food industry is voluntarily implementing security measures to prevent deliberate contamination, with some concerns about sharing sensitive information with federal agencies.
* FDA and USDA lack comprehensive information on the extent to which food processors are implementing security measures, and there are recommendations for additional training and studies on needed authorities. 
</summary>

<summary>
* MAS program is the largest interagency contracting vehicle managed by GSA.
* MACs, GWACs, and enterprisewide contracts are also used by government buyers.
* Agencies spent over $60 billion in fiscal year 2008 through various contracting programs.
* Concerns about duplication of effort and lack of reliable data on interagency contracts.
* Limited governmentwide policy for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
* Recommendations made to improve data collection and oversight of contracting programs.
* Challenges faced by GSA in managing the MAS program, including lack of transactional data.
* GSA lacks comprehensive view of MAS program performance and pricing.
* Ongoing efforts to address issues with interagency and enterprisewide contracts to maximize government buying power.
</summary>

<summary>
* Investments in IT can enrich people's lives and improve organizational performance.
* Both 18F and USDS have provided a variety of development and consulting services to federal agencies, with most agencies being satisfied with the services provided.
* Recommendations are made for GSA to ensure that goals and performance measures are outcome-oriented and for OMB to update USDS policy to define the responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital services teams.
* It is important for USDS and 18F to establish outcome-oriented goals, measure performance, and prioritize projects to effectively deliver digital services and ensure accountability for results.
</summary>

<summary>
* The aging of the baby boom generation will lead to significant changes in the ratio of working-age population to those over 65.
* Changes in Social Security retirement policy may encourage older individuals to work longer.
* Older workers are increasingly participating in the labor force, particularly in white-collar occupations.
* Employers are experimenting with flexible employment arrangements to retain older workers.
* Public employers are implementing programs to incentivize older workers to stay on the job, particularly in response to teacher shortages.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel for business or tourism.
• The program aims to boost international business and tourism, airline revenues, and create economic benefits for the United States.
• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) oversees the VWP and implemented the Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) to enhance security.
• VWP countries must meet specific requirements, including sharing information on security threats and lost passports.
• DHS has not fully analyzed the risks of noncompliance with ESTA requirements by travelers and carriers.
• DHS has not completed biennial country reviews in a timely manner, affecting Congress's ability to assess program vulnerabilities.
• DHS has established procedures to review cases of VWP passengers traveling without verified ESTA approval.
• DHS has made progress in negotiating information-sharing agreements with VWP countries, but not all countries are in full compliance.
• DHS has taken steps to minimize the burden on travelers with ESTA, but some VWP countries have expressed dissatisfaction over the ESTA fee.
</summary>

<summary>
• State child welfare systems are struggling to keep pace with the needs of troubled children and their families.
• The foster care population has grown significantly over the past decade, with federal funds supporting a large number of children.
• States are required to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes.
• Permanency planning processes are in place to find permanent placements for foster children, with regular reviews and hearings.
• Some states have enacted laws to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing.
• Initiatives such as concurrent planning have been implemented to expedite the permanent placement process.
• Challenges in the foster care system include the termination of parental rights and the need for more adoptive homes.
• Evaluation data on the impact of these initiatives is lacking, hindering a full understanding of their effectiveness.
</summary>

<summary>
• The DATA Act requires transparency in federal spending by disclosing agency expenditures and linking spending information to federal program activities.
• OMB and Treasury are responsible for leading government-wide implementation of the DATA Act.
• OMB has issued guidance to federal agencies on reporting requirements under the DATA Act.
• Treasury has developed technical guidance and reporting systems to facilitate agency reporting.
• Agencies face challenges in linking financial and award data using unique identifiers.
• OMB and Treasury need to establish clear policies and processes for developing and maintaining data standards.
• OMB and Treasury should align technical guidance with implementation time frames specified in the DATA Act Implementation Playbook.
• OMB should accelerate efforts to merge DATA Act requirements with the GPRAMA requirement to produce a federal program inventory.
• OMB should establish mechanisms to assess the results of independent audits and reviews of agencies' compliance with the DATA Act requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
* OSC has an agreement with ARC to provide contracting support for a fee.
* ARC is a government-run enterprise that relies on revenue from federal agency customers.
* Interagency contracting involves three parties: the agency requiring a good or service, the agency placing the order, and the contractors.
* OSC may hire intermittent consultants under 5 U.S.C. § 3109.
* OSC's primary mission is to protect federal employees from prohibited personnel practices.
* OSC contracted with MPRI for an organizational assessment without proper competition.
* OSC hired an intermittent consultant, Alan J. Hicks, to address efficiency and curriculum development.
* OSC employees face challenges in addressing prohibited personnel practices involving the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel.
* Recommendations were made to improve management oversight in interagency contracting and ensure proper contracting procedures are followed. 
</summary>

<summary>
* VA's mission is to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of all veterans by providing medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials.
* VA consists of three major components: VBA, VHA, and NCA, responsible for benefits, health care, and burial services.
* VA relies heavily on IT infrastructure to deliver services and benefits to veterans.
* VA has old legacy systems that need modernization or replacement.
* VA's strategic plan focuses on increasing veterans' access to benefits, eliminating disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness.
* VA has allocated significant funds for IT resources, including new systems development and maintenance.
* VA's CIO is leading a transformation effort to improve IT management capabilities and streamline systems development.
* VA faces challenges in interoperability with DOD, modernizing systems, and improving claims processing for care in the community programs.
</summary>

<summary>
• FAA is primarily supported by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes paid by users of the NAS.
• The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system to be more based on cost-based charges.
• The proposed funding structure aims to address concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency by linking FAA's revenues more closely with its costs.
</summary>

<summary>
• HCFA is unique in authority and responsibility among health care payers due to the size and nature of the Medicare program.
• Fee-for-service Medicare serves about 33 million beneficiaries and processes a high volume of claims.
• HCFA is responsible for paying and monitoring more than 400 managed care health plans.
• The Medicare statute divides benefits into two parts: hospital insurance (part A) and supplementary medical insurance (part B).
• Recent acts grant HCFA substantial authority and responsibility to reform Medicare, including enhancing anti-fraud-and-abuse activities and introducing new health plan options.
• HCFA is facing challenges such as loss of experienced staff, reorganization issues, and difficulties in implementing new legislation.
• Managers express concerns about the distribution of agency resources, need for specialized expertise, loss of institutional experience, and reorganization issues.
• HCFA is working on modernizing its information systems, implementing new legislation, and addressing management challenges to improve Medicare program effectiveness.
</summary>

<summary>
* GSA's Federal Technology Service, in conjunction with the IMC, ensures federal agencies have access to necessary telecommunications services.
* FTS2001 program aims to provide best service and price for the government and maximize competition for services.
* GSA awarded contracts to Sprint and MCI WorldCom for long-distance services.
* GSA is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace existing contracts.
* Networx acquisition program has goals to meet agency needs, obtain best value, encourage competition, respond to the marketplace, and provide opportunities for small businesses.
* Networx Universal and Networx Select contracts will be awarded to satisfy different service requirements.
* Challenges include ensuring accurate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring contracts, and planning for a smooth transition.
</summary>

<summary>
* FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs authorized under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, providing over $50 billion in aid to 8 million students annually.
* FSA was established as a Performance-Based Organization (PBO) to improve service, reduce costs, increase accountability, and integrate information systems.
* FSA has made progress in customer and employee satisfaction, but needs to improve reporting on unit cost calculation, systems integration, program integrity, and human capital management.
* Education agreed with recommendations to refine unit cost calculation, establish measurable goals for systems integration, focus on compliance and risk for program integrity, and develop comprehensive human capital strategies. 
</summary>

<summary>
* NIH made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds by September 30, 2010.
* NIH used standard review processes and criteria to award extramural scientific research grants with Recovery Act funding.
* Recipients of Recovery Act funding were required to report on the number of jobs supported on a quarterly basis.
* NIH Recovery Act grantees reported on the number of FTEs supported by the funding.
* Data showed an increase in FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funds from December 2009 to June 2011.
* NIH officials expect Recovery Act funds to eventually support approximately 54,000 FTEs.
* NIH is participating in the Star Metrics program to track the employment, scientific, and economic impacts of funded research projects.
* Principal investigators reported using Recovery Act funding to purchase supplies, equipment, and specialized services for research.
* Some principal investigators provided scientific training to health care professionals as part of their Recovery Act-funded research.
* Preliminary results from research projects supported by Recovery Act funds showed potential developments in preventive medicine, disease detection, and medical therapies. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Transit-oriented development is described as a compact, mixed-use neighborhood near transit stations.
• Various stakeholders, including local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, and private developers, play important roles in planning and implementing transit-oriented development.
• FTA has been expanding its role in transit-oriented development by funding research, coordinating with other agencies, and providing grants for planning efforts.
• Market demand for real estate, available land for development, resident support for transit, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers are key factors that support transit-oriented development.
• Challenges hindering transit-oriented development include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance projects, lengthy approval processes, lack of resident support, and undesirable physical features around transit stations.
• Local governments can encourage transit-oriented development through zoning regulations, area planning, infrastructure investments, and tax incentives that align with market demand and resident preferences.
</summary>

<summary>
* SSA administers two programs, DI and SSI, for individuals unable to work due to disability, with different eligibility requirements and benefits.
* Concurrent beneficiaries, receiving benefits from both programs, face challenges in understanding work incentives and may not take advantage of available provisions.
</summary>

<summary>
* SSA introduced the PEBES in 1988 to help workers review their earnings records and obtain benefit estimates.
* SSA plans to mail PEBES statements to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000.
* Accurate earnings records are important for determining Social Security benefits.
* The PEBES estimates retirement benefits based on certain assumptions about future employment and earnings.
* The PEBES may over- or understate benefits for certain individuals, such as federal workers eligible for both CSRS and Social Security benefits.
* Public reaction to receiving the PEBES has been generally favorable.
* The current PEBES statement is criticized for providing too much information in a confusing manner.
* Recommendations include revising the PEBES layout and design, simplifying explanations, and evaluating alternative formats for communication.
</summary>

<summary>
* CERP efforts in Afghanistan focus on development and construction, while in Iraq the focus is on reconstruction of neglected infrastructure.
* The number and complexity of CERP projects in Afghanistan have increased over time.
* Management and execution of the CERP program is the responsibility of officials at various levels, including CJTF-101 headquarters and brigades.
* Lack of trained personnel and insufficient training are key challenges in effectively managing and overseeing CERP projects.
* Coordination between DOD and USAID is ongoing, but there is a need for a centralized project-development database to improve visibility and eliminate project redundancy.
</summary>

<summary>
• Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast region in August 2005, leading to billions of dollars in damage and human casualties.
• The Stafford Act authorizes the federal government to provide assistance during major disasters like Hurricane Katrina.
• Nearly $88 billion was appropriated by Congress for relief and recovery efforts related to the Gulf Coast hurricanes.
• FEMA administers the Disaster Relief Fund to assist in relief and recovery efforts.
• Mission assignments are issued by FEMA to other federal agencies to support disaster relief efforts.
• FEMA's reporting on obligations and expenditures for mission assignments does not reflect the actual status from a governmentwide perspective.
• There is a lack of mechanisms in place to consolidate and report on the use of the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided to 23 federal agencies.
</summary>

<summary>
* FAA has authority to authorize all UAS operations in the national airspace.
* Currently, FAA allows UAS access on a case-by-case basis through Certificates of Waiver or Authorization, Special Airworthiness Certificates, and Section 333 exemptions.
* FAA issued the UAS Comprehensive Plan and UAS Integration Roadmap to guide UAS integration efforts.
* The phased approach to UAS integration includes Accommodation, Integration, and Evolution phases.
* FAA issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations in February 2015.
* FAA selected six UAS test ranges in December 2013, which have become operational and received authorization for test flights.
* Some countries allow commercial UAS operations under limited circumstances.
* FAA faces challenges in issuing final rules for small UASs, developing an implementation plan, and increasing UAS operations at test sites.
* A public education program called "Know Before You Fly" has been launched to provide information on safe UAS operations.
* NextGen technologies are being developed to facilitate the safe integration of UAS into the national airspace system. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Solar energy technologies include photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.
• Solar projects are supported by federal agencies through various technology advancement activities.
• Over $2.6 billion was obligated for solar projects in fiscal years 2010 and 2011 by six federal agencies.
• Coordination efforts among solar-related initiatives aim to avoid duplication and leverage resources.
• Key practices for enhancing coordination include establishing joint strategies, monitoring progress, and defining common outcomes.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD provides servicemembers with protective ensembles to survive and conduct military operations in the event of a chemical or biological attack.
* Existing protective equipment is bulky, not fully interoperable, and will expire by 2007, prompting the development of new lightweight gear.
* DOD's risk assessment process for wartime shortages of protective equipment is flawed, leading to inaccurate risk assessments.
* Inventory management issues, including inaccurate data, miscalculations, and counting equipment before delivery, contribute to the risk of shortages and affect readiness for operations in contaminated environments.
</summary>

<summary>
* Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to address specific questions about program performance.
* Evaluations can be key in program planning, management, and oversight by providing feedback on program design and execution to program managers, legislative and executive branch policy officials, and the public.
* Factors that facilitate evaluation use include agency leadership support, staff involvement, evaluation relevance to decision makers, and consultation with stakeholders on the agency's evaluation agenda.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Rehabilitation Act defines disability as a physical or mental impairment that limits major life activities.
* Federal efforts aim to promote employment of individuals with disabilities in the federal workforce.
* Special hiring authorities, such as Schedule A, are provided for people with disabilities.
* Executive Order 13548 requires federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities.
* Agencies face challenges in accurately measuring the number of employees with disabilities and implementing the goals of the executive order.
</summary>

<summary>
• BLM's mission is to manage public lands and resources for the American people.
• BLM manages 270 million acres of public lands in 28 states primarily in the West and Alaska.
• BLM's fiscal year 1995 appropriation was $1.24 billion.
• BLM developed the ALMRS/Modernization project to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities.
• The project was scaled down in 1989 due to high costs and is expected to cost $403 million by 2002.
• BLM has been meeting most schedule milestones for the project but may face slippages due to tight timelines.
• BLM plans to stress test the entire ALMRS/Modernization system before deployment to ensure it can handle peak workloads.
</summary>

<summary>
• IAEA is an independent organization affiliated with the United Nations
• IAEA's safeguards objectives are to prevent diversion of nuclear material for weapons
• The Nuclear Suppliers Group helps curb nuclear proliferation by establishing guidelines for nuclear exports
• Strengthened safeguards measures have revealed undisclosed nuclear activities in Iran, South Korea, and Egypt
• Challenges faced by IAEA include limited access to key sites and lack of unfettered inspection rights
• U.S. assistance programs help secure nuclear material and warheads in former Soviet countries
• DOE's programs aim to eliminate excess stockpiles of weapons-usable nuclear material in Russia
• U.S. agencies provide radiation detection equipment to combat nuclear smuggling in various countries
• Challenges faced by U.S. assistance programs include corruption of foreign officials and technical limitations
</summary>

<summary>
• The Year 2000 computing crisis poses a high risk to critical services provided by the government and private sector, with potential disruptions in financial transactions, flights, power, national defense, and key economic sectors.
• Efforts to address the Year 2000 issue in federal, state, and local governments are slow, with challenges in establishing priorities, contingency planning, data exchanges, and end-to-end testing. 
</summary>

<summary>
• IQA consists of two major elements: guidelines for federal agencies to ensure quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information, and administrative mechanisms for correction of information.
• OIRA developed governmentwide IQA guidelines and assisted agencies in developing their own guidelines.
• Agencies faced challenges in implementing IQA, including difficulties in posting IQA information online and addressing correction requests.
• The number of IQA requests declined from over 24,000 in fiscal year 2003 to 62 in fiscal year 2004, with most requests being substantive in nature.
</summary>

<summary>
* Large sponsors of DB pension plans have made revisions to benefit offerings over the last 10 years, including modifying benefit formulas, converting plans to hybrid designs, and freezing some plans.
* Changes to benefit formulas were driven by unpredictability of funding requirements for nonbargaining employees and competitive pressures for collectively bargained employees.
* Health benefits are a significant component of employer offerings, with retiree health benefits being increasingly unlikely for new employees and changes being made to future retiree health offerings.
</summary>

<summary>
* Both mutual fund companies and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and invest them back into the economy.
* Mutual funds invest in securities like bonds and stocks, while banks use deposits to make loans or invest in debt securities.
* The relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining since the 1960s.
* Securitization has reduced the dependence on bank loans for financing, with securities markets becoming a major source of funds.
* Mutual funds have attracted significant amounts of money that might have otherwise been placed in bank deposits.
* The impact of mutual funds on deposits is estimated to be sizable but likely less than $700 billion.
* The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds has not significantly affected the total supply of loanable and investable funds.
* Mutual funds have enhanced liquidity in the securities markets, making it easier for borrowers to tap into these markets for financing.
* Small businesses may be indirectly affected by the movement of funds from deposits to mutual funds, but the overall impact on credit availability is uncertain.
* The channels of financing are varied, and a shift of money from deposits to mutual funds may not necessarily reduce credit availability for borrowers. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Congress passed the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002
• The Act requires activities related to bioterrorism preparedness and response
• The Secretary of HHS is required to establish an integrated system of public health alert communications and surveillance networks
• HHS has funded over $2.7 billion for public health preparedness efforts since fiscal year 2002
• The President established a goal for electronic health records for most Americans within 10 years
• HHS has incorporated public health preparedness and hospital performance goals into funding agreements
• Federal actions have been accelerated to encourage the use of IT for health care delivery and public health
</summary>

<summary>
* A refugee is defined as a person outside their country due to persecution.
* The Refugee Act of 1980 provides a procedure for admitting refugees to the US.
* Federal agencies coordinate with private organizations for resettlement.
* The President determines the maximum number of refugees admitted each year.
* Refugees are assigned to national voluntary agencies for resettlement.
* Three federal agencies are involved in the resettlement process.
* ORR provides temporary resettlement assistance to refugees.
* Communities may face challenges in serving refugees, especially with secondary migration.
* Integration of refugees into communities is a key aspect of resettlement programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established NFIP to provide government-guaranteed flood insurance to homeowners and businesses.
* NFIP has been strengthened through various legislation over the years, including mandatory purchase requirements and grant programs for mitigation.
* NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk flood insurance premiums, with subsidized rates covering about 22% of policies.
* Mitigation efforts, such as elevation and relocation, have been used to reduce flood damage to properties insured by NFIP.
* Increasing premium rates to reflect actual flood risks could reduce costs to taxpayers and encourage private market participation.
* Expanding participation in NFIP could lower premium rates and reduce taxpayer costs by spreading the risk of flooding.
* Encouraging private market participation could transfer risk away from taxpayers, but challenges include affordability concerns and potential rate increases.
</summary>

<summary>
* Section 287(g) of the INA allows state and local law enforcement agencies to perform certain immigration functions under ICE supervision.
* Agreements are not required for communication with ICE regarding immigration status or cooperation in identifying removable aliens.
* ICE has discretion to establish enforcement priorities for the 287(g) program.
* ICE's Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC) manages the 287(g) program.
* ICE offers various programs under ACCESS for state and local law enforcement agencies.
* ICE provides training, equipment, and supervision for participating agencies in the 287(g) program.
* ICE lacks management controls for the program, including defined objectives, supervision guidelines, and performance measures.
* Participating agencies have reported benefits of the program, such as reducing crime, but also concerns about deportation for minor offenses.
* ICE is working on developing performance measures for the program.
* Recommendations include documenting program objectives, clarifying authority usage, defining supervision activities, specifying data collection requirements, and establishing a plan for performance measures. 
</summary>

<summary>
• SEC, NASD, and NYSE have developed guidance for examiners to assess compliance with mutual fund sales practices.
• The regulators periodically provide written guidance related to mutual fund sales practices.
• SEC reviews SRO examination modules during on-site inspections and coordination meetings.
• SEC, NASD, and NYSE coordinate efforts to oversee broker-dealers through joint task forces and conferences.
• The regulators generally do not provide copies of their written examination materials to each other.
• SEC officials believe sharing examination modules could compromise their supervision of the SROs, while NASD and NYSE officials see benefits in sharing such information.
</summary>

<summary>
• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.
• TVA must design its rates to cover all costs while keeping rates as low as feasible.
• TVA can borrow funds through issuing bonds and notes, with a debt ceiling set by Congress.
• TVA's Board of Directors administers the agency and sets goals, policies, and approves budgets.
• TVA aims to reduce its debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through rate increases, limiting operating expenses, and reducing capital expenditures.
• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities and debt reduction plans are not fully reported in a manner consistent with GPRAMA requirements, raising questions about how the agency will meet its goals.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to address concerns about oversight and accountability for federal assistance provided to state and local governments.
• Single audits are organization-wide financial statement audits that focus on internal control and compliance with laws and regulations governing federal financial assistance.
• The quality of single audits has been a longstanding concern, with deficiencies identified in audit planning, internal control testing, and compliance testing.
• The National Single Audit Sampling Project was conducted to assess the quality of single audits and make recommendations for improvement.
• Recommendations to improve single audit quality include revising standards, establishing minimum training requirements for auditors, and enhancing disciplinary processes for unacceptable audits.
</summary>

<summary>
* Medicare is a federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled beneficiaries.
* Part A covers inpatient hospital care, skilled nursing facility care, hospice care, and certain home health services.
* Part B covers physician and outpatient hospital services, laboratory services, and more.
* Claims are processed by 49 claims administration contractors called intermediaries and carriers.
* Intermediaries process part A claims, carriers process part B claims.
* Medicare contracting differs from most federal programs, with no full and open competition for contracts.
* Medicare could benefit from contracting reforms, such as competitive bidding and specialization of contractors.
* The program currently contracts with health insurers for claims administration, but there is a need for more flexibility.
* Implementing changes to contracting would require time, careful planning, and clear evaluation criteria. 
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD focused on reducing support costs to increase investments in modernization.
* DSB identified potential savings of $7-12 billion annually through outsourcing.
* DSB recommended outsourcing all logistics activities to achieve savings.
* PA&E found DSB's savings estimate overstated by $1 billion.
* Legal and cultural barriers hinder full implementation of outsourcing.
* DOD has difficulty in achieving significant cost savings due to infrastructure reductions.
* DSB's savings estimates were considered overly optimistic.
* DOD is encouraged to develop a detailed plan for cost reduction initiatives.
* DOD's cultural resistance to change may impede cost-saving efforts.
* DOD's Defense Reform Initiative Report outlines strategic goals for cost reduction. 
</summary>

<summary>
* Federal agencies, including HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM, underwent downsizing between fiscal years 1993 and 1996.
* Agencies refocused their missions, reengineered work processes, and took steps to build and maintain employee skills to maintain performance during downsizing.
* Performance measurement data showed that agencies generally met or exceeded their goals during downsizing.
* Customer satisfaction remained generally high, although some customers expressed dissatisfaction due to downsizing-related issues.
</summary>

<summary>
* First City Bancorporation of Texas faced financial difficulties in the late 1970s and early 1980s due to high concentration of loans to the energy industry.
* FDIC provided open bank assistance in 1988 to recapitalize First City, but the banks ultimately failed in 1992.
* The recapitalized First City banks relied on nontraditional income sources, leading to unsustainable profits and dividend payments.
* Problems with loan portfolios, high operating expenses, and aggressive lending practices contributed to the banks' failure.
* FDIC considered various resolution alternatives, including bridge banks, to minimize costs and ensure an orderly resolution.
* Lessons learned from the First City experience include the importance of realistic economic assumptions, safeguards in assistance agreements, and early notification of insolvency.
* Regulatory changes, such as FDICIA and FIRREA, provided greater authority to regulators and insurers in dealing with troubled financial institutions.
</summary>

<summary>
* IRS designed the National Research Program (NRP) to measure voluntary reporting compliance and minimize burden on taxpayers.
* NRP consists of casebuilding, classification, and audits to verify information reported on tax returns.
* NRP aims to update return selection formulas, design prefiling programs, and focus resources on noncompliance areas.
* NRP audits are conducted through correspondence or face-to-face methods, with a focus on verifying reported information.
* IRS conducted tests and training sessions to ensure accurate implementation of NRP processes.
* NRP includes quality assurance measures to ensure accurate data collection and minimize errors.
* IRS plans to survey taxpayers subject to NRP audits to assess customer satisfaction and burden.
* IRS consulted with stakeholders to enhance efforts to minimize taxpayer burden in the NRP program.
* GAO did not make any recommendations in the report, recognizing IRS's efforts to gather information and adjust NRP implementation as needed.
</summary>

<summary>
• Thorough planning and preparation are crucial for the cost-effectiveness of large projects like the decennial census.
• The 2000 Census was marked by poor planning, leading to increased costs and risks.
• The Bureau's goals for the 2010 Census include increasing relevance and timeliness of data, reducing operational risk, improving coverage and accuracy, and containing costs.
• The Bureau's three-legged stool strategy includes updating the MAF/TIGER database, implementing the ACS, and modernizing TIGER.
• Challenges for the Bureau include securing congressional approval, addressing methodological questions about the ACS, and ensuring the accuracy and completeness of the census data.
</summary>

<summary>
• Health information technology can improve quality of care and reduce costs
• Electronic prescribing allows for direct transmission of prescriptions between providers and pharmacies
• Federal laws dictate acceptable use and disclosure of health information
• HIPAA and HITECH Act establish privacy and security protections for health information
• OCR enforces HIPAA rules through investigations, corrective actions, and penalties
• HHS has not issued guidance on de-identifying health information as required by HITECH Act
• OCR has not fully implemented periodic audits to ensure compliance with HIPAA regulations
</summary>

<summary>
• The MHSS spends over $15 billion annually on medical readiness for active-duty military personnel.
• The PDP was established to train clinical psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication in response to combat stress.
• The PDP faced implementation problems, including recruitment difficulties and lack of clearly defined roles.
• The cost-effectiveness of the PDP is unclear, with estimates varying based on different scenarios and assumptions.
• The MHSS has no current need for prescribing psychologists, as it has sufficient psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to meet readiness requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
* JWST is a large deployable, infrared-optimized space telescope and the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope.
* The project is facing technical challenges and risks that may impact its schedule and cost commitments.
* Independent oversight, such as Standing Review Boards and the Independent Verification & Validation facility, provides insight into project risks.
* The project has used cost reserves to address technical challenges, particularly related to the cryocooler.
* Recommendations include improving the reliability of contractor data, conducting periodic cost risk analyses, and implementing independent surveillance of EVM data. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Federal agencies are required to protect personal privacy through laws such as the Privacy Act of 1974 and the E-Government Act of 2002, as well as by conducting privacy impact assessments and developing information security programs.
• Challenges faced by federal agencies, such as DHS, include addressing privacy concerns in data mining, passenger prescreening, use of information resellers, RFID technology, and participation in the information sharing environment.
</summary>

<summary>
• Chemical facilities are attractive targets for terrorists, but security has not been comprehensively assessed.
• EPA regulates 15,000 facilities under the Clean Air Act, requiring risk management plans for accidental releases.
• DHS is developing a plan to protect the chemical sector, focusing on high-priority facilities.
• Industry associations promote security measures, but participation in voluntary initiatives is unclear.
• Legislation has been proposed to grant DHS authority to require security measures at chemical facilities.
• Inherently safer technologies could reduce risks, but industry opposes requirements to use them.
• DHS lacks authority to regulate chemical sector security effectively and calls for federal legislation to address this issue.
</summary>

<summary>
• EESA was enacted in 2008 to address the financial crisis affecting the U.S. and global economy.
• Treasury established various TARP programs to stabilize the financial system, including investments in AIG, automotive companies, and financial institutions.
• Housing programs under TARP, such as HAMP and HAFA, aimed to assist homeowners facing foreclosure.
• Treasury has been winding down TARP programs, with some programs showing a lifetime income while others incurred a lifetime cost.
</summary>

<summary>
• Coal-fueled electricity generating units provide a large share of electricity in the US.
• Several environmental laws have been enacted to address concerns over air pollution, water resources, and solid waste.
• EPA has proposed regulations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing fossil-fueled generating units.
• DOE, EPA, and FERC are monitoring industry progress in responding to EPA regulations.
• Power companies are retiring coal-fueled generating units and implementing retrofits to comply with regulations.
• Most retired units are older, smaller, more polluting, and geographically concentrated.
• Power companies are using various technologies to retrofit units, with larger units being the focus.
• Concerns have been raised about reliability and electricity prices due to retirements and regulations.
• Agencies are coordinating efforts to monitor industry progress and address potential challenges.
• The report recommends continued joint monitoring of industry progress in responding to EPA regulations. 
</summary>

<summary>
• Social Security provides benefits to retirees, disabled workers, and dependents, with an average monthly benefit of around $1,051 for retired workers.
• Disability benefits are calculated based on a worker's AIME and PIA, with adjustments made for the number of years worked and the age at which disability occurs.
• Dependents, including widows, widowers, and children, can receive benefits based on a percentage of the worker's benefit amount.
• Social Security faces financial challenges due to the retirement of baby boomers and increasing life expectancy, with deficits predicted to deplete trust funds by 2041.
• Various reform proposals have been made to restore solvency, including changes to benefit calculations and adjustments to the COLA.
• Reform elements such as price indexing, longevity indexing, and progressive price indexing could reduce benefits for disabled workers and dependents.
• Protection options, such as full or partial exemptions, could mitigate the impact of benefit reductions on vulnerable populations.
• Implementing protections for disabled workers and dependents may come at a cost to the Social Security program's solvency and could create incentives for certain individuals to apply for disability benefits.
• Consideration should be given to the implications of reform on disability and dependent beneficiaries, as well as the potential interactions between reform elements and protection options.
</summary>

<summary>
• FSA field offices do not systematically determine the eligibility of all estates kept open for more than 2 years
• FSA did not consistently make the required annual determinations for estates
• Some estates received farm program payments without proper eligibility determinations
• FSA field offices vary in making eligibility determinations, suggesting inconsistent implementation of rules
• FSA made improper payments to deceased individuals due to lack of management controls
• Payments to deceased individuals through entities accounted for a significant portion of post-death payments
• Complex farming operations, such as corporations and general partnerships, increase the potential for improper payments
• USDA reported significant improper payments in farm programs due to poor management controls
• Recommendations were made for USDA to conduct required annual estate eligibility determinations and implement management controls to prevent improper payments
</summary>

<summary>
* FAA's ATC system operates continuously and provides services to various users.
* FAA's modernization projects have faced cost overruns, delays, and performance shortfalls.
* FAA has struggled with acquiring new systems within schedule and cost parameters.
* FAA faces challenges with the year 2000 date requirements and needs to improve its investment management processes.
</summary>

<summary>
• Rule of law programs funded by the United States totaled at least $970 million from 1993-98.
• Funding increased from $128 million to $218 million annually over the period.
• Latin America and the Caribbean received the largest share of funding at 36%.
• Central Europe saw a significant increase in funding, from $9 million in 1993 to over $67 million in 1998.
• Funding for Africa and Latin America declined over the period.
• Problems with USAID's automated information system may have caused a decline in funding reported for 1996.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Foundation, a private nonprofit organization, received $3 million in surcharge coin proceeds from the U.S. Treasury to create a Memorial Garden in Normandy.
• The Foundation faced financial management problems, including significant liabilities exceeding assets, leading to turnover in management and doubts about its ability to continue operations.
</summary>

<summary>
• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises managed by federal employees.
• DOD primarily uses two franchise funds for contracting services—GovWorks and FedSource.
• Franchise funds charge fees for services and are required to recover their full costs of doing business.
• GovWorks and FedSource did not always adhere to competitive procedures and sound contracting practices.
• DOD customers often chose franchise funds based on convenience rather than a strategic acquisition plan.
• GovWorks and FedSource lacked clear oversight plans and did not always define desired outcomes for contracts.
• Recommendations were made to improve DOD's use of franchise funds and ensure compliance with procurement regulations.
</summary>

<summary>
• Wildland fires play an important ecological role in shaping landscapes across the United States.
• Factors affecting federal-nonfederal collaboration to reduce wildland fire risk include federal and state authorities, initiatives, joint planning, agency resources, leadership, education, prevention messaging, and community engagement.
• Actions to improve the ability to reduce wildland fire risk include implementing the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, increasing prevention efforts, improving timber-processing capability, adopting state and local ordinances, and providing insurance incentives.
• Challenges to collaboration include federal and state environmental laws, limited resources, and factors affecting community engagement and prevention efforts.
</summary>

<summary> 
• The U.S. territories have some flexibility in setting Medicaid and CHIP eligibility standards and benefits, but face funding challenges and limited program integrity oversight compared to states. 
• Territories vary in Medicaid program eligibility, benefits coverage, and funding, with recent temporary increases in federal funding helping to avoid funding shortfalls and improve programs. 
</summary>

<summary>• Millions of retirees rely on private and public pension plans, which invest in assets such as stocks, bonds, hedge funds, and private equity to pay retirement benefits.
• Pension plans face challenges in investing in hedge funds and private equity, including limited transparency, liquidity, and operational risks, and must take steps to mitigate these challenges.</summary>

<summary>
* In 1980, Congress passed the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) to establish the Superfund program for cleaning up hazardous waste sites.
* EPA administers the Superfund program and oversees cleanups performed by responsible parties or performs cleanups itself.
* States also have a role in the Superfund process and can enter into agreements with EPA for cleanup actions.
* CERCLA requires EPA to maintain a National Priorities List of hazardous sites for cleanup.
* EPA has evaluated over 40,000 potential hazardous waste sites and made decisions on almost 35,000 for the National Priorities List.
* Many potentially eligible sites pose risks to human health and the environment, with groundwater and drinking water sources being contaminated.
* States have varying capabilities for funding and enforcing cleanup activities at potentially eligible sites.
</summary>

<summary>
* Foreign nationals coming to the US on a temporary basis need an NIV.
* The visa process includes documentation reviews, interviews, biometrics, and name checks.
* Changes post 9/11 have increased complexity and wait times for visas.
* State has initiated policies to strengthen security and manage workload.
* State needs a strategy to address increasing visa demand and reduce wait times.
</summary>

<summary>
* OPM's mission is to ensure an effective civilian workforce, with a major focus on managing the retirement program for federal employees.
* The agency has faced challenges in modernizing the retirement processing system, including issues with cost estimating, EVM, requirements management, testing, and program oversight.
* OPM has not fully implemented key capabilities for retirement modernization, and the program is at risk of failure without addressing these weaknesses.
* Recommendations include developing a complete plan for the program, establishing a reliable cost estimate, implementing effective EVM, developing a requirements management plan, beginning test planning activities early, and improving program oversight.
</summary>

<summary>
• NCIC is a criminal justice information system maintained by the FBI.
• Over 92,000 law enforcement agencies have access to NCIC.
• NCIC contains active records of missing persons.
• NCIC is managed by FBI's CJIS and state/local agencies.
• Policies and procedures for NCIC are documented in manuals.
• CSAs oversee NCIC use at the local level.
• CJIS conducts audits of CSAs to ensure compliance with policies.
• CJIS audits include assessing compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement for missing children reports.
• Challenges in timely reporting of missing children include custody disputes and coordination with child welfare agencies.
</summary>

<summary>
• The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency in the US has grown dramatically over the last 2 decades.
• The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) was passed in 1968 to educate students with limited English proficiency.
• Four bilingual education grant programs were created under the BEA to distribute funds to school districts serving children with limited English proficiency.
• Most services for children with limited English proficiency are funded with local and state dollars, not federal funds.
• Education's Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs (OBEMLA) administers the four competitive bilingual education grant programs.
• The four bilingual education programs share the same performance goals and measures, possess similar eligibility criteria, and allow similar uses of program funds.
• Program consolidation may provide benefits such as reducing administrative burden, increasing efficiency, and allowing for greater emphasis on collaboration between grantees and other programs supporting children with limited English proficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Coast Guard is a multimission maritime military service within the Department of Homeland Security.
* The Coast Guard is organized into two major commands, 9 districts, and 35 sectors to execute missions.
* The Coast Guard's budget request in fiscal year 2008 reflects a focus on reorganization efforts and addressing operational challenges in programs such as Deepwater, Nationwide Automatic Identification System, and Rescue 21.
</summary>

<summary>
* Tobacco is a high-value, pesticide-intensive crop, with the US being a major producer and exporter.
* Pesticides used on tobacco can pose health risks, especially to workers handling them.
* EPA conducts risk assessments to evaluate potential health impacts of pesticides on humans.
* USDA regulates and tests pesticide residues on tobacco to ensure they do not exceed allowable limits.
* Other countries, such as Germany, Italy, and Spain, have set limits on pesticide residues in tobacco products.
</summary>

<summary>• DOD's personal property program, known as Families First, is used to manage household goods moves for military servicemembers and DOD civilians when they relocate.
• The program involves a complex process of qualifying carriers, soliciting rates, distributing moves, evaluating moving companies' performance, paying invoices, and settling claims.
• DOD previously evaluated three pilot programs and submitted recommendations to Congress in 2002 to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers.
• DOD developed a new program called Families First to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers, DOD civilian employees, and their families.
• The program involves implementing performance-based service contracts, information technology improvements, and reengineering the liability and claims process.
• DOD's personal property system has used the Transportation Operational Personal Property Standard System (TOPS) since 1989, but TOPS is being phased out due to technical limitations.
• DOD expects TOPS to be functional for a large part of the Families First rollout until DPS is fully operational.
• DOD faces challenges in implementing DPS, including delays, missed milestones, and significant software problems.
• DOD's estimated cost for implementing Families First and DPS has increased significantly, and the department has not set aside funding to fully cover these costs.</summary>

<summary>
* Automobiles have been associated with nearly 29,000 traffic fatalities annually in the United States.
* Crash severity is the most important predictor of driver hospitalization or death, followed by crash type, safety belt use, driver age and gender, and automobile weight.
* Safety belts greatly reduce the risk of injury and death in roadway crashes.
* Men drivers and younger drivers are more likely to be involved in crashes, but less likely to be injured compared to women and older drivers.
* Safety belts with automatic pretensioners or web locking devices are more effective in reducing serious injuries.
* NHTSA regulations require all cars to have air bags and manual lap and shoulder safety belts by September 1997, but automatic safety belts may offer greater protection in serious crashes.
</summary>

<summary>
* In school year 2009-2010, the District of Columbia's school system enrolled over 72,300 students across 58 local educational agencies, including DC Public Schools and public charter schools.
* Federal payments were provided to support various initiatives in both DC Public Schools and public charter schools, with a focus on improving facilities, academic programs, staff incentives, and student access to college preparation programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* User financing through user fees, charges, or excise taxes is a way to finance federal programs.
* User fees should be fair and based on costs, value of service, and public policy.
* The distinction between fees and taxes can be complex and depends on context.
* User fees should align with the beneficiary-pays principle to promote equity.
* Agencies should regularly review and update fees to ensure they cover program costs.
* Stakeholder input is important in fee design and agencies should communicate fee information transparently.
</summary>

<summary>
• Agencies need to separate wants from needs to ensure best return within fiscal constraints
• Agency budgets may not be linked to strategic goals or consider resource limitations
• Agencies often pursue individual needs over collective needs
• Congressional direction may require unnecessary purchases or services
• Agencies budget incrementally based on historical precedents rather than strategic goals
• Lack of portfolio management leads to wasted investments on wants over needs
• Fragmented decision-making processes lead to lack of consideration for agencywide needs
• Individual program decisions may undercut sound policies
• Challenges in contract management include unrealistic requirements, inadequate oversight, and frequent staff turnover
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD's procurement process, specifically the Standard Procurement System (SPS), has faced challenges in meeting user needs, cost-benefit expectations, and progress against commitments.
* The economic analysis for SPS has not justified further investment, and incremental investment management practices have not been followed, leading to risks of investing in a system that may not produce commensurate value.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD establishes a standard price per barrel for fuel customers based on crude oil price, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs.
* Differences between estimated and actual fuel costs were primarily due to fluctuations in fuel prices and differences in estimated vs. actual fuel consumption.
* DOD uses the Defense-wide Working Capital Fund to purchase bulk fuel and adjusts the standard price to manage fluctuations in cash balance.
* DOD has not updated its approach for setting the standard price since 2007, leading to significant differences between estimated and actual costs.
* Recommendations include reevaluating the approach for estimating standard price components and documenting assumptions.
* DOD concurred with reevaluation recommendation but partially concurred with documenting assumptions recommendation.
* DOD faces challenges in setting a standard price that reflects actual fuel costs and has not fully documented its rationale for setting the standard price.
* Studies conducted since 2004 have provided recommendations for managing bulk fuel costs and working capital funds, but DOD has not fully implemented them.
</summary>

<summary>
• USCIS processes millions of immigration benefit applications each year, with a focus on fraud detection and investigation.
• USCIS has a staff of about 3,000 permanent adjudicators located in service centers and district offices.
• USCIS has a backlog of several million applications and has developed a plan to eliminate it by the end of fiscal year 2006.
</summary>

<summary>
• IRS' performance during the 1994 filing season was assessed
• IRS exceeded accuracy and timeliness goals for processing refunds
• EIC continued to be a leading source of errors in tax returns
• IRS identified a growing number of fraudulent refund claims
• Taxpayers faced difficulties reaching IRS by telephone for assistance
• IRS implemented measures to improve processing efficiency and fraud detection
</summary>

<summary>
• Medicaid was established in 1965 as a jointly funded federal-state program providing medical assistance to qualified low-income persons.
• Each state designs and administers its own Medicaid program, subject to federal requirements for eligibility, services covered, and provider payments.
• States may obtain waivers from HCFA under the authority of section 1115 of the Social Security Act to control costs and implement managed care systems.
• Tennessee was the first state to move its Medicaid program enrollees to a statewide demonstration project called TennCare.
• TennCare expanded coverage to uninsured and uninsurable persons, increased scope of coverage, and extended coverage periods for Medicaid-eligible persons.
• TennCare implemented a capitated managed care system by contracting with 12 MCOs to provide delivery of all Medicaid acute and primary care services.
• TennCare faced challenges with rapid implementation, confusion among enrollees and providers, delays in claims processing, and premium payment collection.
• Financial performance of MCOs under TennCare was weak in the first year, with some MCOs reporting losses and delays in claims processing.
• TennCare faced issues with provider participation, communication, and outreach, leading to delays in signing providers and assigning patients to primary care providers.
• TennCare experienced problems with premium payment collection from uninsured enrollees, resulting in terminations of coverage for non-payment and past due premiums.
</summary>

<summary> 
• Major structural changes in the American economy in the 1970s led to worker dislocation, prompting the implementation of worker profiling and reemployment services to assist claimants in finding new jobs. 
• While early studies showed positive impacts of the worker-profiling initiative, data limitations and lack of ongoing evaluation have raised concerns about the program's current effectiveness and the need for federal oversight. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The rapid increase in crack cocaine use in the 1980s was considered a drug epidemic.
* Federal agencies like ONDCP, NIDA, and SAMHSA were responsible for detecting and responding to changes in drug use patterns.
* Changes were made to drug detection mechanisms to improve accuracy and timeliness of data.
* Recommendations were made to improve the completeness, accuracy, and usefulness of drug data and to develop a defined strategy for addressing emerging drug problems.
</summary>

<summary>
• The military health system has three missions: maintaining the health of active-duty service members, maintaining readiness for wartime casualties, and providing care to dependents, retirees, and survivors of military personnel.
• TRICARE framework was implemented in the mid-1990s to improve beneficiary access and quality while containing costs.
• TRICARE offers three options: Prime, Extra, and Standard, covering inpatient and outpatient services, skilled nursing, and prescription drugs.
• Medicare covers health care expenses for the elderly, some people with disabilities, and those with end-stage kidney disease.
• Military retirees aged 65 or older are eligible for Medicare and TRICARE For Life.
• The Medicare subvention demonstration allowed DOD to create managed care organizations for older retirees, with Medicare paying DOD for enrollees' care.
• DOD's costs for providing care to Senior Prime enrollees were higher than what Medicare could pay, resulting in no payment from Medicare in 1999.
</summary>

<summary>
* NTSB has fully implemented or made significant progress in implementing leading management practices in various areas.
* NTSB has fully implemented three management recommendations and made further progress on eight recommendations since 2008.
* NTSB has taken steps to implement IT-related recommendations and has made progress in limiting local administrator privileges.
* NTSB has drafted a strategic training plan and obligated funds for a cost accounting system.
* NTSB has made progress in improving knowledge management and human capital planning, but diversity management remains a challenge.
* NTSB has implemented recommendations related to investigating accidents and has developed policies for selecting accidents to investigate.
* NTSB has increased the use of its Training Center and reduced its operating deficit.
* NTSB has proposed changes to its authorizing legislation to investigate incidents and reduce requirements for rail and maritime investigations.
* NTSB has made progress in implementing recommendations to increase the use of safety studies and the Training Center.
</summary>

<summary>
* GPRA shifts focus of government decisionmaking to results and outcomes achieved by federal programs
* EPA's annual performance plans inform Congress and public of goals, measures, strategies, and procedures
* EPA funds diverse programs to control pollution of air, land, and water
* EPA works with states to manage environmental programs
* EPA reported progress in improving air quality and reducing toxic emissions
* EPA's strategy for clean air involves working with states and implementing the Acid Rain Program
* EPA reported progress in achieving safe and clean drinking water goals
* EPA works to clean up hazardous waste sites and ensure responsible parties pay cleanup costs
* EPA reported progress in ensuring food is free from unsafe pesticide residues
* EPA made improvements in its performance reports and plans, but challenges remain in human capital management and information security
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) initiated the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices and information technology use.
* CIM aimed to streamline operations, eliminate redundant systems, and save costs through business process reengineering.
* DOD faced challenges in integrating CIM efforts across functional areas, gaining support from managers, and clarifying program management authority.
* Recommendations included active participation of functional managers, employee training, and renaming the initiative to improve understanding and acceptance.
</summary>

<summary>
* Undercover investigation involved producing counterfeit documents and transporting radioactive sources across borders.
* Investigators successfully passed through border checkpoints with counterfeit documents and radioactive sources.
* CBP inspectors did not question the validity of the counterfeit documents during inspections.
* Corrective action briefings were conducted with CBP and NRC officials to address the issues identified during the investigation.
* NRC officials disagreed with the amount of radioactive material needed to produce a dirty bomb.
* Concerns raised about the potential security risks posed by the ability to counterfeit documents and transport radioactive sources. 
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD relies on research labs, industry, and academia to develop new technologies for military operations.
* Transition programs like ACTD and FCT aim to bring technologies out of the lab and into real use.
* Challenges in technology transition include funding, technology maturity, and communication between labs and acquisition programs.
* Recommendations include developing data and measures for program assessment, implementing feedback mechanisms, and strengthening communication between program managers, developers, and acquirers.
</summary>

<summary>
* The MAF is a data file used for census and demographic surveys in the US.
* The Bureau is researching targeted address canvassing to update the MAF more efficiently.
* The Bureau's schedules for MAF development have reliability issues.
* The Bureau is working on workforce planning to address scheduling skill gaps.
* Collaboration practices within the Bureau are being implemented to support MAF development goals.
</summary>

<summary>
• OJJDP established the Girls Study Group in 2004 to develop research on preventing and reducing girls' delinquency.
• The Study Group identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency and assessed their effectiveness using What Works criteria.
• The group found that most programs had not been studied, and none of the studies provided conclusive evidence of effectiveness.
• OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance to help programs prepare for evaluations and support promising programs.
• The Study Group recommended additional rigorous evaluations, training, and funding for girls' delinquency programs.
• OJJDP is in the process of developing a plan to address girls' delinquency goals and is taking steps to meet those goals.
• A recommendation was made for OJJDP to develop and document a plan with specific funding requirements and time frames.
• OJP agreed with the recommendation and outlined efforts to address girls' delinquency issues.
• OJJDP plans to publish a proposed juvenile justice program plan in the Federal Register by the end of the year.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Clean Air Act was passed in 1963 to regulate air pollution from stationary and mobile sources.
• The act was substantially overhauled in 1970, 1977, and 1990 to set national ambient air quality standards and reduce emissions.
• States are responsible for developing implementation plans to comply with EPA standards.
• EPA has made progress in reducing emissions of major air pollutants since 1970.
• Despite improvements, many Americans still live in areas where air pollution exceeds federal standards.
• EPA identified 452 actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.
• Many requirements were met late, with an average delay of 24, 25, and 15 months for Titles I, III, and IV, respectively.
• EPA cited factors such as stakeholder involvement, competing demands, and new scientific information for delays in meeting requirements.
• EPA has completed most of the required actions related to Titles I, III, and IV, but some requirements remain unmet.
• The report highlights the challenges and progress in implementing the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.
</summary>

<summary>
• DFAS was created in 1991 to standardize DOD finance and accounting policies and procedures.
• Prior to 1991, military services had separate finance and accounting operations that were duplicative and inefficient.
• DFAS consolidated finance and accounting operations from military services and defense agencies.
• DFAS is funded through operations and maintenance appropriations from military services and defense agencies.
• DFAS reduced the number of finance and accounting systems used in DOD from 324 to 217.
• DFAS is responsible for processing payments to DOD personnel, retirees, annuitants, contractors, and vendors.
• DFAS is also responsible for collecting debts owed to DOD from individuals and contractors.
• DOD's finance and accounting activities are divided into nine functional areas, with DFAS and military services sharing responsibilities.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as the country's central bank with a decentralized structure.
* The Federal Reserve operates independently and is subject to oversight by Congress.
* The Reserve Banks are not federal agencies but are federally chartered corporations with a board of directors.
* The Federal Reserve's monetary policy decisions aim to promote maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates in the United States.
</summary>

<summary>
* Thieves turn stolen cars into money in three ways: chop shops, obtaining valid titles, and exporting abroad.
* The 1992 Act established a task force, a national title information system, and a parts marking program to combat car theft.
* The task force recommended uniform definitions for salvage vehicles, titling and control methods, and duplicate title issuance.
* The National Stolen Auto Part Information System (NSAPIS) was recommended to be administered by NICB with oversight from an advisory committee.
* NSAPIS would provide automatic notifications to law enforcement on stolen vehicle parts, meet security requirements, and encourage manufacturers to provide updated information.
* The NSAPIS Committee recommended electronic theft status verification, limited immunity for participants, and verification tasks for insurance carriers.
* Insurers would be required to verify major parts of salvage vehicles, impounded vehicles would be verified through NSAPIS, and self-insured entities would perform verifications.
</summary>

<summary>
* Prescription drug distribution involves interactions among wholesalers, independent pharmacies, PSAOs, and third-party payers.
* Three wholesalers dominate the drug distribution market in the US.
* Independent pharmacies play a significant role in drug sales, especially prescription drugs.
* PSAOs negotiate contracts with third-party payers on behalf of independent pharmacies.
* PSAOs provide services such as contract negotiation, communication, and help-desk support to pharmacies.
* PSAOs may charge monthly fees for bundled services to member pharmacies.
* Most PSAOs are owned by wholesalers or independent pharmacy cooperatives.
* PSAOs aim to create administrative efficiencies for pharmacies and third-party payers. 
</summary>

<summary>
* Enterprise architectures are a blueprint that describes the current and desired state of an organization or functional area in both logical and technical terms.
* Various federal departments and agencies have reported varying levels of satisfaction with their enterprise architecture tools and frameworks.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement was signed in 2006 after seven months of negotiation, aiming to promote economic growth and democracy in the Middle East.
* The agreement includes provisions for tariff reductions, protections for labor and the environment, and commitments to open markets in various sectors such as banking, insurance, and telecommunications.
</summary>

<summary>
• Exchange rate policies of East Asian nations have been a source of tension with the United States.
• Some countries are accused of intentionally keeping their currencies undervalued for competitive advantage.
• Different exchange rate policies include fixed, free float, and managed float.
• The U.S. Treasury monitors major trading partners for currency manipulation.
• Some East Asian countries have been accused of asymmetric foreign exchange interventions.
• U.S. policy generally supports free float exchange rate policies, but many East Asian governments prefer managed float policies.
</summary>

<summary>
* China's economy heavily relies on global trade and investment flows.
* China's net exports contributed to one-third of its GDP growth in 2007.
* FDI flows to China have been a major factor behind its productivity gains and rapid economic growth.
* The global economic slowdown has negatively impacted China's export sector and industries dependent on FDI flows.
* China's stimulus package aimed to boost infrastructure projects and promote consumer spending.
* China's economic recovery showed positive signs in 2009, with GDP growth and stock market index rising.
* Concerns over long-term growth prospects include heavy reliance on bank lending and infrastructure spending.
* China's role in responding to the global financial crisis remains uncertain, with concerns over its large holdings of U.S. securities.
</summary>

<summary>
* U.S. ambassadors serving as Chiefs of Mission play a crucial role in coordinating interagency activities and overseeing U.S. government activities in their assigned countries.
* The President appoints ambassadors with the advice and consent of the Senate, and they serve as the President's personal representatives.
* The Foreign Service Act of 1980 outlines the responsibilities and authority of Chiefs of Mission, including coordination and supervision of all government executive branch employees in their country of assignment.
* COM authority extends to all executive branch agencies, except for Voice of America correspondents and personnel under the command of a Geographic Combatant Commander.
* COM authority is shaped by legislation, executive orders, and presidential directives, with the President's Letter of Instruction providing detailed guidance on a COM's authority.
* COMs are responsible for coordinating all U.S. government activities in their host country, including military personnel, under the general direction of the Secretary of State.
* COM authority does not extend to the legislative and judicial branches, but COMs are responsible for keeping the President and Secretary of State informed of all activities in their country.
